@ThamesPathNT @passedwonder @cllrrobwhite @EnvAgencySE Central London is fine. The #Thames is too wide and deep here to flood from rainfall as the lower fluvial Thames would flood first.

Could be west London Flood Alerts issued from tomorrow morning as the tides are due to rise.

@AdamBaylissEA @PaulBurrowsy @GsBrand @Elygroupofidbs @EnvAgencyAnglia Well said Adam. A really good and insightful tour by Paul today of a complex water/flood management system of the Great Ouse Fens. One with a long history, but as vital today as ever. Ouse Washes surely has to be one of the 7 wonders of water management in Britain, if not Europe.
@lizwatts101 @bill_handley55 @EnvAgencyAnglia @CambsCC @CambsCops @cambsfrs @SouthCambs Hope everything will  be OK Local government at  work

@CambsCops @cambsfrs @EnvAgencyAnglia @CambsCC @huntsdc We walked along the river near Stetham, no problem there. The problem is Earith Bridge, the hundred and forty foot , and Denver sluice, and the tide.

text: @EnvAgencyAnglia Well done all - working hard over Christmas and through a tough year. Not been an easy 2020 for lots of the FCERM community but we’re pulling through one day at a time.

@PaulBurrowsy @GsBrand @Elygroupofidbs @EnvAgencyAnglia Good tweets this week @PaulBurrowsy. Good amount of information to keep people informed 👏

Who knows.... I might be down in your patch soon enough & I already feel like I know parts of it 🤓

@ThamesPathNT @cllrrobwhite @EnvAgencySE 'Most places' makes me want to go and check that Central London's still okay... 😉 OTOH, enjoying a well-earned day off after a *lot* of wandering in the last week, so I'll leave it 'till tomorrow to see the embankments are still there!

@AnglianWater @dthomas83uk @EnvAgency Totally understand your point,and sympathise! Just disappointed that it took 3 calls and a councillors tweet to get it prioritised, averting a much bigger issue.Technician arrived within the hr, tanker on the way and Enviromental impact study starts tomorrow 👍 Thankyou🙏

@johncurtinEA @EnvAgency Great stuff. One question though - how do you know how many properties flooded? Is that simply intersection of flood warning areas and rooftop lat longgs or actual reports of flooded properties?
